Evaluation_Questions: What percentage of the reading and other assignments did you complete?
Comments_Questions: How well was the course organized?
How effective was the balance between instruction and discussion?
How well did the assigned papers, reports or other projects reflect the aims of the course?
How did the amount of assigned reading work with weekly discussion?
How did the supplementary materials (files, videos, recordings, etc.) for the course enhance your experience of it?
The course filled a significant gap in your knowledge of the field.
Regardless of whether or not the course is required, would you recommend it to other students in and outside the department?
The course goals were clearly presented.
The instructor has a strong grasp of the course subject matter.
The instructor presented the subject matter effectively.
The instructor was willing to consider diverse points of view.
The instructor was willing to answer pertinent questions.
The grading criteria was clearly explained.
The instructor was available for consultation, discussion and advice.
I would recommend this instructor to other students.
How many of the 14 class meetings did you attend?  Comments:
Please offer additional comments you have on such topics as: what worked best about the course, what improvements you would suggest, etc.
How would you rate the overall usefulness of discussion sections for this class?
Was enough time devoted to discussion sections?
Did you attend all the discussions?
Comments_List: There is a lot of thought and information put into the class. It is a lot to take in.
Paul has lecture organization down to an art

Excellent survey of theater from Ancient to 17th Century civilizations. I appreciated the diversity of cultures covered while emphasizing Western Theater because of its relevance to American Theater. 

Readings, Lectures (including TA lectures), and assignments were clear, valuable and interesting.
The course is incredibly well-organized. If there were any questions we were always able to sort them out immediately with Paul or our TAs.

Paul Walsh cares deeply about this course. He changes it every year to respond to the needs of the previous year, actively grappling with how to best teach his students this important material in a way that is helpful for creating new work.

The easy availability of resources was fantastic. I don't think there was a single time I looked for something and was unable to find it. 
There was occasionally a lack of clarity in some areas (only example I can think of was whether or not the final exam essay questions would be made available ahead of time), but this did not have a huge impact.

Paul does an excellent job of preparing lectures and content for class. While absorbing this much information was, at times, overwhelming, I felt stronger and more knowledgeable at the the end of the course.

My discussion section was not strong. I did not feel we adequately discussed the information presented in class in the discussion.  While my peers may not have been the most responsive to certain prompt questions, the section was often awkward due to unclear prompts or silences.

Nahuel did a magnificent job at inspiring thoughtful conversations and debates. He did not shy away from pressing students (in a supportive manner) to deepen and justify their arguments.

The lectures are dense, and Nahuel perfectly balanced rehashing key concepts with in depth discussions of important issues/frameworks.
I truly appreciated both the lectures and the discussion sections.
I think the discussion was a little uneven to the lectures.
The TAs nicely balanced a close read of the plays and a review of larger themes.

The discussion groups were the best part of the class. Not being able to ask questions during class and just listening to an essay being read to us was very hard to learn from. Maybe posting what Paul is reading from on Canvas would be useful for people to look at on their own.
I think that the amount of time allocated to discussion groups was good, but I don't feel as though my discussion group made the best possible use of this time.
I loved my discussion group and wish we had gotten more time together. Nahuel is an amazing TA.
I didn't need the discussion portion. It often felt forced at best, and at it's worst it was being forced to sit through a tutoring session for others in my group.

Because lectures are so packed with information there is little time for questions and discussion is effectively limited to the TA groups. This leads to every TA group having a very different discussion and leaving the room with varying takeaways.
The tests are a great format. I understand the purpose of the paper, but would have preferred not to have done it.  The test format of essay questions are a great way to synthesize the knowledge.

The paper presented a new challenge that shed light on the process of an academic approach to theater. The weekly discussion sections were almost always inspired relevant, intriguing structures for analyzing the plays we read.
I think the combination of two essay based exams and a paper are perhaps overkill. Lightening the essay portions of the exams would feel a little less repetitive.
yes. very clearly.
The paper was more so just interesting to write, but I don't think it enhanced my theater history knowledge.

The gist of the class paper was pretty appropriate to the aims of the course. Unfortunately, its proximity to the midterm made it difficult to devote a lot of time to it. Also, the list of largely unfamiliar plays, presented with little context, made it difficult to make an informed choice about an unfamiliar play. 

Not all of the short response questions felt useful or related to the play. The question about 'The Mandrake' stood out as somewhat frustrating.

While I did enjoy writing the paper, it felt unfair and tedious that the exams were essays, as well. Due to the spectrum of learning types and creative sensibilities in the room, I had hoped that theere would be alternative ways to be evaluated.

The paper feels like a method of having an additional grade, to help those who don't test well. I didn't feel that I learned anything more from it, either in terms of how to write papers or in terms of the subject of the course.

Some readings were more dense than others. I would have preferred to have the lecture before reading the play, as I gained more insight from knowing about the history of the time period.  I reviewed slides ahead of time, but the lecture supplements really informed the readings.
Gavin Whitehead lead excellent discussions

Goldilocks: Not too much, not too little. I appreciated that we did not have to read many (or any) very long plays, while the brevity of some plays still communicated and demonstrated the form of the times to the class.
We couldn't always talk about both plays in the discussion if two plays were assigned for that week, but we did a pretty good job.
I thought so. I didn't feel overwhelmed by the reading, and they worked contextually to the weekly lectures.
The reading was mostly manageable, and provided enough material for discussion.

It's hard to have good discussions when not everyone reads. It's also hard to have good discussions when the plays themselves are often dry and hard to read.

Theatre is meant to be seen, not read - why can't we see productions instead? Or films of productions? This would allow us to understand concepts and stories much more easily, instead of getting stuck on colloquialisms and bad writing.

It's a lot of reading and at certain times when there are multiple shows in tech or there was a lot going on in the production calendar, it was difficult to keep up with the assigned reading as well as homework for other courses. I would encourage more mindfulness of the production calendar when choosing plays and devising the syllabus.
I appreciate the supplemental info.
I honestly didn't really look at them due to lack of time so they probably would have been helpful if I really wanted to dig into a time period some more but I didn't feel compelled to do that.

There were few examples of supplementary media (videos/recordings) and I didn't read the suggested supplementary papers to the class. One suggestion might be to require the class to read/watch VERY small excerpts of supplementary materials. The class has the perfect amount of assignments overall, so substantial additional time spent on supplementary materials would not be worthwhile.
Multimedia files never really mattered when it came to exam preparation since it's all last minute cramming.
I never had time to used the supplementary materials and did fine in the class. Not sure how much more they would've helped or hurt.
I did not always manage to make use of these, but they were useful when I did.
I have learned a lot and am grateful for the space to do it.

I majored in Theater Studies in undergrad, so there was some overlap with my previous knowledge. However, I worked at a Shakespeare company for the last decade and I had never heard of (or didn't remember) the influence of the Vagabond Laws. I thought the class's unique perspective on the Greeks and 16-17th Century English drama was particularly novel.

The course is structured well but given the time crunch all the information we received this semester will be forgotten by next year so that really isn't helpful. If there were fewer topics or details to study and focus on, it would be easier to get a comprehensive understanding, rather than learning a lot of random facts.
Very much so.

What I will remember from this course are the review sessions with the TAs: zooming back out to big picture again, comparing and contrasting different strands of theater history across time and space. An invaluable overview that would have been missed with just the tests alone (it is easy to get caught up in close reading and memorizing, forgetting the bigger picture).

Just listening and watching a power point isn't my learning style which made actually taking in this class very hard. Most/all of my learning happened when studying for the test and looking at the power points on my own and through the review session with the TAs. I don't think that really helped me retain anything, but I'm sure I have something in the back of my mind that wasn't there before.

Having not completed an undergraduate degree in a field related to theatre or drama, this course absolutely filled a gap in my knowledge. I feel better equipped as both a theatre/drama student and practitioner.
Yes. It can be dense, but I really learned from it.

It would depend on the learning style of the student. While it is all important information for me learning all that information so quickly, I don't think I will retain that much of it. I need to really dig into topics and when skimmed the surface to cover the volume that I will only retain bits and pieces from the course. If someone learned from a fast paced lecture style then I would definitely recommend.
Yes, I would. For what we do, a solid understanding of theatre history is required.

Yes, the undergrad in our section was one of the most critical, thought-provoking classmates, and I appreciated her presence. I have encouraged others reasons for not testing out in the spring and to audit our spring class.
If you like reading lots of plays then yes take this class.
Yes. I loved having such a breadth of theatrical instruction, as I think it will greatly aid my in my next few years here, and into the field in general.
It's a very engaging overview of a lot of complex material!

I would recommend that course to students. It's much better than my undergraduate Theatre History course because of Paul. His enthusiasm for the material is unparalleled. its clear how much he cares about his students and desires them to understand the material as well as take something with them. Were it taught by someone else, I don't know that I would recommend it.

I would absolutely recommend this course. Having a strong foundation in theater histor[ies] makes you a better artist. This course didn't just cover the western cannon, but explored how different cultures crafted different kinds of theater, theater shaped by and shaping local politics, economics, and social relations.

Yes, if there weren't tests and you were just there to learn what you were able to soak up in class. 

No, if there are tests. It's not worth trying to cram enough information into your brain to pass the test.
Yes.
I would only recommend it to those that enjoy classic approaches to academia.

I learned more about theatre history in this course than I did in the ones I took in undergrad - this I can't deny. That said, I wouldn't recommend it to anyone in my program. It simply takes up a slot that could be filled with a more relevant course.

If I were speaking to a non-grad student, or someone with room in their schedule, I would be more likely to recommend it.

****ALSO IF IT WEREN'T THE FIRST COURSE OF THE DAY, MORE PEOPLE WOULD GET SOMETHING OUT OF IT****
I did not study theater during undergrad, so for me the course was very impactful. However, I know for many this was a glorified refresher of theater history from college.

I know the idea was to gain a knowledge of theater history, but it went so fast with not a lot of room for in class discussion that wasn't based on the play we read that week in our discussion groups.
Paul is great.

Paul was a great teacher! While I don't love the style of the class he was incredibly knowledgable and caring with the class and would look things up and bring them to class when he didn't know the answer. Paul made the class interesting and more bearable considering I don't enjoy lectures!
Very clearly so.

Paul is like a walking theater encyclopaedia, and I mean that in the best way possible. This is what makes it all the more a shame that the lectures are so fast and dense there is little time for discussion with Paul.
The pace moves quickly and it can be hard to follow sometimes, but he is open to questions and concerns.

Honestly, I felt like because there was so much information we didn't spend enough time on some topics. Now that is just because that's how I learn the best. I liked when we spent a lot of time on a specific play like an entire lecture on Fuentovejuna. Being able to connect the terms back to a play was where I was most engaged. I think Paul was teaching the best way he could to cover all the necessary information but its just such a high volume that it was not the most effective for me personally.

It took all my academic faculties to absorb material and take notes during lectures. The lectures are very dense and akin to listening to a scholarly paper being read out loud. The slides often have too many words to read in the moment, but they are useful study guides for midterms/finals. Often I felt that by the time I started writing down a sentence Paul was saying, I missed the second half of the sentence that contained the most important content.

Personally, I would like to use a laptop to take notes as I'm a faster at typing than writing. If Paul is worried about people "surfing" in class, he can position TAs in the back of class to watch students' screens.

I felt sympathy for ESL students or students who have not been exposed to such rigorous academic environments. However, to my knowledge, many of those students found the support they needed to pass the class if they sought it out.

Overall, I appreciated the challenge of the subject matter's presentation.
Paul is a very entertaining speaker who obviously prepares his lectures meticulously.  I do not feel as though it is an effective mode of presenting the material in a weekly class setting.

Often discussion go off on a tangent and it's hard to keep track of all the names and dates being thrown at us. Also the PPTs are designed in a slightly confusing way such that they make sense during class presentation but if one needs to refer to it later during exams, it's difficult to go back and forth and understand the slides.

I thought Paul did a great job of managing the amount of material covered each class the first part of term. Post mid-term, though, perhaps because we had more to cover, we really raced through the material. The first half of the term, I was able to follow along and take notes without problem. Some days second half of the term, I realized very quickly that I would be unable to take notes because of how rapidly the slides were moving and how quickly we were going through the material.
Having access to the thing that Paul reads in class would be very useful especially since that document already exists because he's actively just reading from it in class.

I have heard from some students that the lectures are a little dense, or that information is presented too quickly, but I personally didn't have a problem with either of these elements, and found the lectures very engaging.
While the subject matter was presented effectively, I do not think that all brain types are easily able to engage in the presentation style.

I could have taken the lectures on my own time. Paul lectures in such a book-on-tape style, that I could take that recording, set to the powerpoint, and used it on my own time.

This would have been just as effective, probably moreso, than sitting/sleeping through the class.
Paul really listens.
Well balanced World Cultures vs. Western Civ.
Paul does this excellently. I especially appreciated that he started the course with African and Native American culture.
It is hard to say as our discussions mostly happened with the TAs.
There is no room in the lecture for discussions, so there is no room for points of view other than Paul.
Lectures are a one-way communication where students are passive receivers of information.
Paul was absolutely willing to answer pertinent questions WHEN THERE WAS TIME. Leaving time for the questions was sometimes an issue.

Willing on the very few days we had 2-5 minutes left at the end of the class. Never willing to entertain questions during the lecture because "he doesn't like to be interrupted." Which is what he told us on the first day of class.
You can't ask questions during the lectures. It may as well be a recording.
As mentioned earlier, the content and pacing do not allow much time to ask questions, let alone for them to be answered.
It is good, though we do not get much feedback as to where we stand in the class during it.
It didn't feel like the grading was consistent across the board between TAs
Clearly on the syllabus.
Though exactly how participation in discussions was graded was unclear. Everything else was very clear.
Although I am not upset with any of the grades I received, I am a little unclear as to how I got them.
Grading seemed to arbitrarily vary from TA to TA making it difficult at times to manage expectations.
Paul is very thoughtful, engaging, and conversational in his discussions with the students.

Paul is incredibly available for all of the above. He is so available that he almost seems honored if you ask him a question. I don't know of any other teacher that I've had within my educational history who has been so encouraging of his students and has wanted them to succeed in the way that Paul does.
Paul is intelligent and friendly.
He's a great teacher!
Paul is a great instructor and a nice person to talk to
I think Paul is an excellent instructor. I've already answered this question above.

Yes. I think the world of Paul Walsh. He cares deeply about the material and about how each student grapples with the material. I hope that his future students continue to treat the class with the respect that Paul so clearly gives.
Only after explaining his teaching style. If that isn't how your brain works I would not recommend him.

I learned more about theatre history in this course than I did in the ones I took in undergrad - this I can't deny. That said, I wouldn't recommend it to anyone in my program. It simply takes up a slot that could be filled with a more relevant course.

If I were speaking to a non-grad student, or someone with room in their schedule, I would be more likely to recommend it.

****ALSO IF IT WEREN'T THE FIRST COURSE OF THE DAY, MORE PEOPLE WOULD GET SOMETHING OUT OF IT****
All of them.
All but one because I had to go home for a funeral.
All but one.
All of them
All of them.
All of them. I was late one morning by two minutes.
All.
All but one. I was sick
I missed 3 of the big group classes and one of the discussions groups. One of those was because I was in the hospital.
I attended every class and TA group session.
I really enjoyed this class as it was presented. Sure it's difficult, and it's hard to give it full attention for every class, but it is still a good class.
Different speakers were a nice interruption and different type of perspective.

I would just encourage him to continue to slow down just a little. I know that this has been feedback he's gotten in the past. I'd say he's almost there, but could go one or two notches slower. Other than that, I very much enjoyed the class.

Remove the tests, but keep the paper. Online weekly responses and the paper should be enough to grade the class. The tests are an added stress that does not help actually learn the material in the way the class is currently taught. 

Have at least one day with the entire group for discussion in some topic. The fact that this is the only class where you get almost all of the 1st years together is a major lost opportunity since this class is mostly lecture.

On the whole I feel the course did an amazing job of covering so much material in the allotted time. 
I feel as though there were certain areas that were overrepresented in terms of time spent on them. In particular, we seemed to spend a great deal of time on the development of scenery and theatre architecture which, while interesting, felt perhaps less important than some of the other subject matter.

Please make this a NOT 9am class. This would be a huge step forward in making it more accessible.

Please provide lecture recordings. I understand that "attendance is mandatory" but I would have gotten just as much, if not more, out of the course if I could have done it in my own time. Only the discussion sections felt like something I needed to be there at the time-of matter.
It was poorly run.  We weren't sure what was expected of us.  Discussions were difficult to maintain.

Some days were more helpful than others. I think there was again just so much information in the lectures that I needed more time to process what I heard before going straight into section to ask the right questions but I think it was good for the most part.

Nahuel is an incredible teacher, I strongly wish I could be placed in his section again next semester. Whoever's section I am placed in for the Spring will have big shoes to fill.

I did feel that the review session for the Final Exam was not as useful as the one for the Midterm. TAs weren't as clear and got caught up in different opinions about definitions rather than surveying all the concepts as they had done for the midterm review. It was a minor blip on the radar of an excellently taught course.
Gavin was a good teaching assistant.
While I greatly enjoyed my discussion section, I felt as though other sections were used more for overview and prep for exams than mine was.
I feel it was those discussion sections that had any direct impact in clarifying course material.

To be honest, I don't know how useful they were to understanding the material. HOWEVER, I thought they were great because it gave us a common piece of writing to discuss interdepartmentally and within mixed years. It helped me get to know other artists within the community and have some lively discussions.
We actually were given the time to ask real questions.
In theory, the discussions are excellent. In practice, I feel, my group did not make the best use of the time.

Some were useful, in that I got to hear other perspectives. Most felt like large tutoring sessions, where no new or interesting information was gleaned. I would have done just as well in the course with just the lectures.
We often ended a few minutes early due to a lack of discussion.
Sometimes the instructor would go over which was problematic because I had a class 5 minutes after this one was supposed to be over, but I think the amount of time in general was good.
I would have liked more time with the discussion groups.

In my group, the allotted time was enough and sometimes more generous than was necessary. I would have appreciated using some of that time to go a little slower in lecture or to ask deeper questions of Paul.
Yes.
All but one because I had to go out of town for a funeral.
all but one
Yes.
Yes.
Only missed 1
Yes
Yes.
Yes.
All but one. I missed one Thursday class on whole due to being ill.
I missed one when I was in the hospital.
I missed one due to illness.
Yes
I attended every discussion session.
